questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the anatomy of the kidney?

options.label: A
options.text: Right renal artery is longer than left renal artery

options.label: B
options.text: Right renal vein is longer than left renal vein

options.label: C
options.text: Left renal artery is longer than right renal artery

options.label: D
options.text: The anterior most structure at renal hilum is the renal artery

questions.correct_answer: A. Right renal artery is longer than left renal artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Right renal artery is longer than left renal artery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: In fact, the left renal vein is longer than the right renal vein because the left renal vein has to cross the midline in front of the aorta to reach the inferior vena cava , while the right renal vein has a shorter and more direct path to the inferior vena cava.
  • • Option B:
  • • left renal vein is longer than the right renal vein
  • • left renal vein has to cross the midline in front of the aorta to reach the inferior vena cava
  • • Option C: The left renal artery is not longer than the right ; it is typically shorter because the aorta lies closer to the left kidney .
  • • Option C:
  • • left renal artery is not longer than the right
  • • shorter because the aorta lies closer to the left kidney
  • • Option D: In the typical anatomical arrangement, the most anterior structure at the renal hilum is the renal vein . The sequence from anterior to posterior is usually the renal vein, followed by the renal artery, and then the renal pelvis.
  • • Option D:
  • • most anterior structure at the renal hilum is the renal vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The right renal artery is longer than the left renal artery due to the relative positions of the aorta and the inferior vena cava , which necessitates a longer course for the right renal artery to reach the right kidney .
  • ➤ right renal artery is longer than the left renal artery
  • ➤ relative positions of the aorta
  • ➤ inferior vena cava
  • ➤ longer course for the right renal artery to reach the right kidney
  • ➤ Left renal vein is longer than right renal vein (hence left kidney is preferred for donor nephrectomy) Right renal artery is longer Anterior to posterior structure of hilum: Vein → Artery → Renal Pelvis
  • ➤ Left renal vein is longer than right renal vein (hence left kidney is preferred for donor nephrectomy)
  • ➤ Left renal vein is longer than right renal vein (hence left kidney is preferred for donor nephrectomy)
  • ➤ Left renal vein is longer than right renal vein
  • ➤ Right renal artery is longer
  • ➤ Right renal artery is longer
  • ➤ Right renal artery is longer
  • ➤ Anterior to posterior structure of hilum: Vein → Artery → Renal Pelvis
  • ➤ Anterior to posterior structure of hilum: Vein → Artery → Renal Pelvis
  • ➤ Anterior to posterior structure of hilum: Vein → Artery → Renal Pelvis
  • ➤ Ref : Sabiston textbook of surgery 20 th edition pg 2069
  • ➤ Ref : Sabiston textbook of surgery 20 th edition pg 2069

questions.text: Microscopic Hematuria is defined when there are more than?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 3-5 RBCs/hpf

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Microscopic hematuria is a clinical condition characterized by the presence of an abnormally high number of red blood cells in the urine that cannot be seen with the naked eye but can be detected using a microscope or a dipstick test during a urinalysis . It is typically defined as three or more red blood cells per high power field on microscopic examination of urinary sediment from at least two out of three urine samples.
  • • Microscopic hematuria
  • • characterized by the presence of an abnormally high number of red blood cells in the urine
  • • cannot be seen with the naked eye
  • • detected using a microscope or a dipstick test
  • • urinalysis
  • • three or more red blood cells per high power field
  • • Here are some of the conditions that can cause microscopic hematuria:
  • • Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs): These can cause irritation of the bladder or urethra and result in bleeding. Kidney Stones: These can breach the lining of the urinary tract as they pass through, causing bleeding. Glomerular Diseases: Conditions affecting the glomeruli, the filtering units of the kidneys, such as glomerulonephritis or IgA nephropathy, can cause blood to leak into the urine. Medications: Some drugs, like anticoagulants and anti-inflammatory medications, can induce bleeding in the urinary tract. Trauma: Blunt/penetrating renal trauma Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH): In men, an enlarged prostate can cause irritation or blockage of the urinary tract and result in bleeding. Systemic Diseases: Conditions such as sickle cell disease or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can also cause hematuria.
  • • Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs): These can cause irritation of the bladder or urethra and result in bleeding.
  • • Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs):
  • • Kidney Stones: These can breach the lining of the urinary tract as they pass through, causing bleeding.
  • • Kidney Stones:
  • • Glomerular Diseases: Conditions affecting the glomeruli, the filtering units of the kidneys, such as glomerulonephritis or IgA nephropathy, can cause blood to leak into the urine.
  • • Glomerular Diseases:
  • • Medications: Some drugs, like anticoagulants and anti-inflammatory medications, can induce bleeding in the urinary tract.
  • • Medications:
  • • Trauma: Blunt/penetrating renal trauma
  • • Trauma:
  • • Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH): In men, an enlarged prostate can cause irritation or blockage of the urinary tract and result in bleeding.
  • • Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH):
  • • Systemic Diseases: Conditions such as sickle cell disease or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can also cause hematuria.
  • • Systemic Diseases:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Microscopic Hematuria - > 3-5 RBCs/hpf

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Intravenous urogram (IVU)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A: X-ray KUB This stands for Kidneys, Ureters, and Bladder X-ray . It's a plain radiograph typically used to assess the abdominal area for the presence of kidney stones , calcifications , or abnormal gas patterns. It doesn’t involve contrast and is often the first imaging test done for patients with suspected kidney stones.
  • • Option A: X-ray KUB
  • • stands for Kidneys, Ureters, and Bladder X-ray
  • • plain radiograph
  • • assess the abdominal area for the presence of kidney stones
  • • calcifications
  • • abnormal gas patterns.
  • • Option C: Retrograde Pyelogram This is a procedure where a catheter is placed via the urethra , bladder , and then into the ureter . Contrast is injected retrograde (upwards) into the ureter and kidney. This is usually done during a cystoscopy. The image doesn’t indicate this process as there is no visualization of catheter placement.
  • • Option C: Retrograde Pyelogram
  • • procedure where a catheter is placed via the urethra
  • • bladder
  • • then into the ureter
  • • Option D: Micturating cystourethrogram:
  • • Option D: Micturating cystourethrogram:
  • • Contrast is injected in the bladder via a catheter or intravenously , patient is asked to micturate and X ray is taken . It shows bladder and urethra with contrast.
  • • Contrast is injected in the bladder
  • • catheter
  • • intravenously
  • • micturate and X ray is taken

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intravenous Urography (IVU) is an imaging modality that uses intravenous contrast to visualize the urinary system, including the kidneys, ureters, and bladder, on X-ray images taken at different time intervals . It is particularly useful for identifying urinary tract disorders such as obstructions, stones, and tumors.
  • ➤ Intravenous Urography
  • ➤ imaging modality
  • ➤ intravenous contrast to visualize the urinary system,
  • ➤ kidneys, ureters, and bladder, on X-ray images
  • ➤ different time intervals
  • ➤ Ref : Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28 th edition pg 1475
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28 th edition pg 1475

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with recurrent UTI underwent an IVU as shown below. What is pathology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ureterocele

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: VUR (Vesicoureteral Reflux) Vesicoureteral reflux is the backward flow of urine from the bladder into the kidneys and ureters . This condition often presents in children and can be associated with recurrent UTIs . However, it is inferred from the retrograde flow of contrast (not seen here).
  • • Option A: VUR (Vesicoureteral Reflux)
  • • backward flow of urine from the bladder into the kidneys and ureters
  • • presents in children
  • • associated with recurrent UTIs
  • • Option B: Posterior Urethral Valves This condition is characterized by the presence of abnormal folds of tissue in the posterior urethra , which can cause obstruction and is generally found in male infants . It would not be the pathology in question for a 15-year-old girl.
  • • Option B: Posterior Urethral Valves
  • • presence of abnormal folds of tissue in the posterior urethra
  • • obstruction and is generally found in male infants
  • • Option D: Cystocele A cystocele occurs when the bladder herniates into the anterior vaginal wall due to weakness of the supporting pelvic floor muscles. It is more common in older women and typically does not present with a 'cobra head' sign on imaging.
  • • Option D: Cystocele
  • • bladder herniates into the anterior vaginal wall due to weakness of the supporting pelvic floor muscles.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of a 'cobra head' sign on the IVU in a patient with recurrent UTIs is indicative of a ureterocele .
  • ➤ 'cobra head' sign on the IVU in a patient with recurrent UTIs
  • ➤ ureterocele
  • ➤ Ureterocele is a cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter , which probably occurs due to atresia of the ureteral orifice. It has a female-to-male ratio of 4:1 and occurs bilaterally in 10% cases. In childhood, they usually present with infection. When large, they can obstruct the bladder neck or even the contralateral ureteric orifice. The classic feature of a ureterocele on an intravenous urogram (IVU) is the ‘cobra head’ sign. The treatment of simple ureteroceles is surgical excision with reimplantation of the ureter. Endoscopic incision of a ureterocele is the preferred treatment method for simple ureteroceles in infants and small children, but may result in subsequent ureteric reflux. A non-functioning kidney may need nephrectomy.
  • ➤ Ureterocele is a cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter , which probably occurs due to atresia of the ureteral orifice.
  • ➤ Ureterocele
  • ➤ cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter
  • ➤ It has a female-to-male ratio of 4:1 and occurs bilaterally in 10% cases.
  • ➤ female-to-male ratio of 4:1
  • ➤ bilaterally in 10% cases.
  • ➤ In childhood, they usually present with infection. When large, they can obstruct the bladder neck or even the contralateral ureteric orifice.
  • ➤ The classic feature of a ureterocele on an intravenous urogram (IVU) is the ‘cobra head’ sign.
  • ➤ The treatment of simple ureteroceles is surgical excision with reimplantation of the ureter.
  • ➤ Endoscopic incision of a ureterocele is the preferred treatment method for simple ureteroceles in infants and small children, but may result in subsequent ureteric reflux. A non-functioning kidney may need nephrectomy.
  • ➤ Ref : Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28 th edition pg 1467
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28 th edition pg 1467

questions.text: Identify the plane that the line marked in the below picture represents:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Plane of avascularity

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Plane of Vascularity This would indicate an area of the kidney that has a rich blood supply . However, the marked line is not known to represent a vascular plane, so this is not the correct choice.
  • • Option A: Plane of Vascularity
  • • area of the kidney
  • • rich blood supply
  • • Option B: Plane of Trauma There is no specific "plane of trauma" in renal anatomy , so this option does not apply to the marked line.
  • • Option B: Plane of Trauma
  • • no specific "plane of trauma" in renal anatomy
  • • Option C: Plane of Cysts/Tumours While cysts or tumors can occur in various places in the kidney , there isn't a specific anatomical plane that predisposes the kidney to cysts or tumors, making this option incorrect for the marked line.
  • • Option C: Plane of Cysts/Tumours
  • • occur in
  • • various places in the kidney

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brodel’s line represents an avascular plane along the kidney , which is crucial for surgeons to recognize and utilize during renal surgeries to minimize blood loss and avoid damage to the kidney's vascular supply .
  • ➤ Brodel’s line
  • ➤ avascular plane along the kidney
  • ➤ surgeons to recognize
  • ➤ utilize during renal surgeries to minimize blood loss
  • ➤ avoid damage to the kidney's vascular supply
  • ➤ The avascular plane of Brodel is the section of renal parenchyma between 2/3 anterior and 1/3 posterior kidneys on the cross-section that is relatively avascular. The reason for its relative avascularity is that it represents the plane where the anterior and posterior segmental renal artery branches meet.
  • ➤ The avascular plane of Brodel is the section of renal parenchyma between 2/3 anterior and 1/3 posterior kidneys on the cross-section that is relatively avascular. The reason for its relative avascularity is that it represents the plane where the anterior and posterior segmental renal artery branches meet.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the urology clinic with a history of recurrent kidney stones. He reports severe pain in the flank area, and imaging studies reveal the presence of multiple renal calculi. The patient has tried various treatments in the past with limited success. The urologist discusses the option of Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL) as a treatment for the stones, considering their size and composition. Which type of renal calculi is resistant to Extracorporeal Shock-Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cystine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognizing that cystine stones are particularly resistant to shock wave treatment helps in planning the appropriate management strategy, potentially incorporating alternative methods such as pharmacological treatment or different types of lithotripsy. This knowledge is crucial for urologists and healthcare providers involved in the treatment of patients with kidney stones, ensuring they choose the most effective and patient-appropriate treatment option.
  • ➤ Recognizing that cystine stones are particularly resistant to shock wave treatment helps in planning the appropriate management strategy, potentially incorporating alternative methods such as pharmacological treatment or different types of lithotripsy.
  • ➤ This knowledge is crucial for urologists and healthcare providers involved in the treatment of patients with kidney stones, ensuring they choose the most effective and patient-appropriate treatment option.

questions.text: A 64-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with low backache not responding to NSAIDs. His PSA levels are 100 ng/ml, and MRI of the spine shows lytic lesions at L5-S1. A per rectal examination reveals an asymmetrically enlarged stony hard prostate. Which of the following drugs is indicated in the management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Goserelin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Goserelin, a GnRH agonist, is used in the treatment of advanced prostate cancer by inhibiting testosterone production. Elevated PSA levels and metastasis indicate advanced disease requiring hormone therapy.
  • ➤ Goserelin, a GnRH agonist, is used in the treatment of advanced prostate cancer by inhibiting testosterone production.
  • ➤ Elevated PSA levels and metastasis indicate advanced disease requiring hormone therapy.

questions.text: A patient was operated on for benign prostatic hyperplasia. On evaluation, incidentally, cancer of the Prostate was detected and on further workup was found to have metastasis. Which of the following drug is used for treatment?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Goserelin

questions.text: A 75-year-old male presents with symptoms of increased urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia, and difficulty in voiding. Upon examination, the prostate is smooth and non-tender. What are the storage symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia? Urgency Enuresis Hesitancy Frequency Dribbling
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) presents with two types of symptoms: storage symptoms (urgency, frequency, nocturia, urge incontinence) due to bladder irritation, and voiding symptoms (hesitancy, poor flow, dribbling, sensation of incomplete emptying) due to obstruction of urine flow. Proper differentiation between these symptoms aids in diagnosing and managing BPH.
  • ➤ Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) presents with two types of symptoms: storage symptoms (urgency, frequency, nocturia, urge incontinence) due to bladder irritation, and voiding symptoms (hesitancy, poor flow, dribbling, sensation of incomplete emptying) due to obstruction of urine flow.
  • ➤ storage symptoms
  • ➤ voiding symptoms
  • ➤ Proper differentiation between these symptoms aids in diagnosing and managing BPH.

questions.text: In performing transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), maintaining urinary continence post-procedure is crucial. Which anatomical landmark signifies the limit of inferior resection in TURP to preserve the external sphincter mechanism and ensure continence?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Verumontanum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The verumontanum is the anatomical landmark that marks the proximal margin of the external sphincter. During TURP, resection should not extend beyond the verumontanum to avoid damaging the external sphincter and causing incontinence.
  • ➤ The verumontanum is the anatomical landmark that marks the proximal margin of the external sphincter.
  • ➤ During TURP, resection should not extend beyond the verumontanum to avoid damaging the external sphincter and causing incontinence.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Which of these is not an indication to perform TURP?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increased frequency

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Acute urinary retention. This is an indication for TURP when it is caused by BPH and cannot be managed medically.
  • • Option A: Acute urinary retention.
  • • indication for TURP
  • • Option B: Residual urine volume greater than 200 mL. Significant post-void residual urine volume indicates inadequate bladder emptying and can be an indication for TURP.
  • • Option B: Residual urine volume greater than 200 mL.
  • • post-void residual urine volume
  • • inadequate bladder emptying
  • • Option D: Presence of bladder diverticula. Diverticula can be complications of longstanding BPH due to high-pressure voiding , and their presence can be an indication for TURP.
  • • Option D: Presence of bladder diverticula.
  • • Diverticula
  • • complications of longstanding BPH due to high-pressure voiding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ TURP is considered when a patient experiences complications of BPH , such as urinary retention, significant post-void residual urine, bladder stones, recurrent urinary tract infections , or bladder diverticula . Increased urinary frequency alone is not typically an indication for TURP.
  • ➤ TURP
  • ➤ patient experiences complications of BPH
  • ➤ urinary retention, significant post-void residual urine, bladder stones, recurrent urinary tract infections
  • ➤ bladder diverticula
  • ➤ Increased urinary frequency
  • ➤ not typically an indication for TURP.
  • ➤ Indications for prostatectomy:
  • ➤ Indications for prostatectomy:
  • ➤ Acute retention Chronic retention and renal impairment: a residual urine of 200 mL or more, hydroureter or hydronephrosis demonstrated on ultrasound, uraemic manifestations and abnormal renal function (accounts for 15% of prostatectomies). Complications of Bladder outlet obstruction: stone, infection and diverticulum formation. Haemorrhage: these patients present with recurrent haematuria with no obvious cause and a very vascular prostate can be seen on cystoscopy. Elective prostatectomy for severe symptoms: this accounts for about 60% of prostatectomies. Frequency alone is not a strong indication for prostatectomy.
  • ➤ Acute retention
  • ➤ Chronic retention and renal impairment: a residual urine of 200 mL or more, hydroureter or hydronephrosis demonstrated on ultrasound, uraemic manifestations and abnormal renal function (accounts for 15% of prostatectomies).
  • ➤ Complications of Bladder outlet obstruction: stone, infection and diverticulum formation.
  • ➤ Haemorrhage: these patients present with recurrent haematuria with no obvious cause and a very vascular prostate can be seen on cystoscopy.
  • ➤ Elective prostatectomy for severe symptoms: this accounts for about 60% of prostatectomies. Frequency alone is not a strong indication for prostatectomy.
  • ➤ Elective prostatectomy for severe symptoms: this accounts for about 60% of prostatectomies. Frequency alone is not a strong indication for prostatectomy.
  • ➤ The natural progression of outflow obstruction is variable and rarely gets worse after 10 years. Severe symptoms not responding to drug therapy, a low maximum flow rate (<10 mL/s) and an increased residual volume of urine (100–250 mL) are relatively strong indications for operative treatment.

questions.text: An 80-year-old patient with benign prostatic hypertrophy complained of dizziness, nausea, vomiting after resection of large prostate by TURP. What is the most probable cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Water intoxication

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Anemia due to blood loss. Although blood loss can occur during TURP and cause symptoms like dizziness , it would not typically cause nausea and vomiting.
  • • Option A: Anemia due to blood loss.
  • • blood loss can occur during TURP
  • • cause symptoms like dizziness
  • • Option C: Glycine toxicity. Glycine is often used as an irrigant during TURP , and while toxicity can occur , it usually presents with visual disturbances or encephalopathy. It's less likely to cause nausea and vomiting alone.
  • • Option C: Glycine toxicity.
  • • used as an irrigant during TURP
  • • toxicity can occur
  • • visual disturbances or encephalopathy.
  • • Option D: Hypoglycemia. There is no direct link between hypoglycemia and TURP . Hypoglycemia would not typically be expected as a complication of this procedure unless there was a preexisting condition or medication interaction.
  • • Option D: Hypoglycemia.
  • • no direct link between hypoglycemia
  • • TURP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Water intoxication , or TURP syndrome , can occur postoperatively due to the absorption of irrigation fluids . This can lead to hyponatremia and present with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, confusion, and dizziness . Treatment typically involves fluid restriction and careful management of electrolyte balance.
  • ➤ Water intoxication
  • ➤ TURP syndrome
  • ➤ postoperatively due to the absorption of irrigation fluids
  • ➤ lead to hyponatremia and present with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, confusion, and dizziness
  • ➤ Absorption of water into the circulation at the time of TURP can give rise to congestive cardiac failure, hyponatremia and haemolysis. Patient presents with confusion and other cerebral events often mimicking a stroke. The treatment consists of fluid restriction.
  • ➤ Absorption of water into the circulation at the time of TURP can give rise to congestive cardiac failure, hyponatremia and haemolysis.
  • ➤ Patient presents with confusion and other cerebral events often mimicking a stroke.
  • ➤ The treatment consists of fluid restriction.
  • ➤ Ref : Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1530
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1530

questions.text: Which of these is the best treatment for Polycystic kidney disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Kidney transplant

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Rovsing's Operation This procedure involves deroofing of cysts and was traditionally used to relieve symptoms in PKD . However, it is not a definitive treatment for PKD, especially as it does not prevent the progression of the disease to end-stage renal disease (ESRD).
  • • Option A: Rovsing's Operation
  • • deroofing of cysts
  • • traditionally used to relieve symptoms in PKD
  • • Option C: Nephrectomy Nephrectomy, or surgical removal of the kidney , may be necessary in cases of severe pain, infection, or massive enlargement of the kidneys due to cysts . It is not a cure for PKD.
  • • Option C: Nephrectomy
  • • surgical removal of the kidney
  • • cases of severe pain, infection, or massive enlargement of the kidneys due to cysts
  • • Option D: Anderson-Heynes Dismembered Pyeloplasty This is a surgical procedure used to treat ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction , a condition typically unrelated to PKD. Therefore, it is not a relevant treatment for PKD.
  • • Option D: Anderson-Heynes Dismembered Pyeloplasty
  • • surgical procedure used to treat ureteropelvic junction
  • • obstruction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best treatment for Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) when it progresses to end-stage renal disease is a kidney transplant. Other treatments like Rovsing's operation or nephrectomy may be used for symptomatic relief but do not address the underlying genetic disorder . Anderson-Heynes dismembered pyeloplasty is not a treatment for PKD as it's indicated for UPJ obstruction.
  • ➤ best treatment for Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease
  • ➤ progresses to end-stage renal disease is a kidney transplant.
  • ➤ Rovsing's operation
  • ➤ nephrectomy
  • ➤ used for symptomatic relief but do not address the underlying genetic disorder
  • ➤ ADPKD has variable penetration and approximately 50% of affected individuals eventually develop end-stage renal disease (ESRD).
  • ➤ ADPKD has variable penetration and approximately 50% of affected individuals eventually develop end-stage renal disease
  • ➤ ADPKD – autosomal dominant, systemic disease:
  • ➤ ADPKD – autosomal dominant, systemic disease:
  • ➤ Rarely manifests before the fourth decade. Hypertension, abdominal pain, haematuria or a palpable flank mass are common presentations. Control of hypertension can delay progression.
  • ➤ Rarely manifests before the fourth decade.
  • ➤ Hypertension, abdominal pain, haematuria or a palpable flank mass are common presentations.
  • ➤ Control of hypertension can delay progression.
  • ➤ Best treatment for ADPKD – Kidney transplant
  • ➤ Best treatment for ADPKD
  • ➤ Rovsing's surgery – Deroofing of cysts. Not done anymore.

questions.text: 35-year-old healthy male is presented with a gunshot wound to the right upper thigh region. On examination, the patient was hemodynamically stable. Which of the following is known as “work-horse” suture material in general surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Polyglactin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Polyglactin (Vicryl) is commonly considered the "work-horse" suture in general surgery due to its reliability, predictable absorption, and minimal tissue reactivity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of nephrolithiasis presents with severe left flank pain and nausea. Preliminary ultrasound findings suggest hydronephrosis. As his clinician, you consider further diagnostic measures. Which of the following statements about hydronephrosis is false?

options.label: A
options.text: The least invasive technique for diagnosis is ultrasound KUB

options.label: B
options.text: Best diagnostic modality to confirm obstructive dilatation is DTPA scan

options.label: C
options.text: Retrograde pyelography confirms the site of obstruction

options.label: D
options.text: IVU can be used in functional and non-functional kidneys

questions.correct_answer: D. IVU can be used in functional and non-functional kidneys
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) IVU can be used in functional and non-functional kidneys

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: The least invasive initial imaging technique for diagnosing hydronephrosis is ultrasound of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder (KUB). It is non-invasive, widely available, and can quickly identify dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces.
  • • Option A:
  • • least invasive initial imaging technique
  • • diagnosing hydronephrosis is ultrasound of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder
  • • Option B: The best diagnostic modality to assess for obstructive dilation within the renal collecting system is a renal scintigraphy scan , such as a diethylene triamine pentaacetic acid (DTPA) scan. This test provides functional information about drainage and can quantitatively assess differential renal function and the presence of obstruction.
  • • Option B:
  • • assess for obstructive dilation within the renal collecting system is a renal scintigraphy scan
  • • diethylene triamine pentaacetic acid (DTPA) scan.
  • • Option C: Retrograde pyelography is an invasive procedure that involves the insertion of a scope into the urethra and bladder to visualize the ureters and collecting system . It can delineate the site and cause of an obstruction in the urinary tract.
  • • Option C: Retrograde pyelography
  • • invasive procedure that involves the insertion of a scope into the urethra
  • • bladder to visualize the ureters
  • • collecting system

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An intravenous urogram (IVU) is not useful for non-functional kidneys because it requires the kidney to excrete contrast to visualize the urinary tract . For diagnosing hydronephrosis , ultrasound is the least invasive method , a DTPA scan is the best to confirm obstructive dilation , and retrograde pyelography can localize the site of obstruction.
  • ➤ intravenous urogram
  • ➤ not useful for non-functional kidneys
  • ➤ requires the kidney to excrete contrast to visualize the urinary tract
  • ➤ hydronephrosis
  • ➤ ultrasound is the least invasive method
  • ➤ DTPA scan is the best to confirm obstructive dilation
  • ➤ IVU can be used only if the kidney is functional.
  • ➤ IVU can be used only if the kidney is functional.
  • ➤ Ultrasound is the least invasive technique for diagnosing hydronephrosis. Retrograde pyelography can confirm the site of obstruction. Intravenous urogram (IVU) is helpful only if the obstructed kidney is functional. Renal isotope scan (DTPA or MAG-3 ) is the best modality to confirm the obstructive dilatation of the collecting system.
  • ➤ Ultrasound is the least invasive technique for diagnosing hydronephrosis.
  • ➤ Retrograde pyelography can confirm the site of obstruction.
  • ➤ Intravenous urogram (IVU) is helpful only if the obstructed kidney is functional.
  • ➤ Renal isotope scan (DTPA or MAG-3 ) is the best modality to confirm the obstructive dilatation of the collecting system.
  • ➤ Ref : Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of surgery 28 th edition Pg 1468-69.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with seizure, recurrent gross hematuria and left flank abdominal pain. questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Option B: Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD ) is characterized by the presence of numerous cysts in both kidneys , which can lead to abdominal pain and hematuria. However, angiomyolipomas are not a hallmark of this disease.

  • • presence of numerous cysts in both kidneys
  • • lead to abdominal pain and hematuria.
  • • Option D: Hereditary Leiomyomatosis and Renal Cell Cancer (HLRCC) HLRCC, previously known as hereditary angiolipoma, is associated with cutaneous leiomyomas and an increased risk of renal cell carcinoma , not angiomyolipomas.
  • • Option D: Hereditary Leiomyomatosis
  • • Renal Cell Cancer
  • • cutaneous leiomyomas
  • • increased risk of renal cell carcinoma

This genetic disorder is associated with various benign and malignant tumors , including renal angiomyolipomas , and requires a multidisciplinary management approach.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of ovarian cancer treated with chemotherapy and radiotherapy presents to the emergency department with frank hematuria. An ultrasound of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder (USG KUB) reveals a chronic contracted bladder. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Radiation induced cystitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A: Metastasis to the bladder. While patients with a history of malignancy can have metastasis to the bladder , this typically presents with more focal lesions rather than a generalized bladder contraction.
  • • Option A: Metastasis to the bladder.
  • • history of malignancy can have metastasis to the bladder
  • • Option B: Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder. This type of bladder cancer can present with hematuria, but it would not typically cause a contracted bladder on imaging.
  • • Option B: Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder.
  • • type of bladder cancer can present with hematuria,
  • • Option D: Chemotherapy-induced cystitis. Certain chemotherapy drugs can cause cystitis , but they typically cause acute inflammation rather than chronic bladder contraction.
  • • Option D: Chemotherapy-induced cystitis.
  • • chemotherapy drugs can cause cystitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Radiation-induced cystitis is a late complication of pelvic radiotherapy , characterized by a contracted bladder and presenting with hematuria . Treatment options include symptomatic management, cystoscopic interventions, and potentially more radical surgeries like urinary diversion or cystectomy for severe cases.
  • ➤ Radiation-induced cystitis
  • ➤ late complication of pelvic radiotherapy
  • ➤ contracted bladder
  • ➤ presenting with hematuria
  • ➤ Radiation cystitis is a common complication of pelvic radiotherapy with incidence rates ranging from 23% to 80%. Radiation treatment causes endothelial cell damage and perivascular fibrosis, resulting in ischaemia and obliterative endarteritis. Haematuria is a common symptom. The end stage is a small, fibrotic bladder Rx- Cystoscopic management with fulguration or laser to bleeding vessels OR urinary diversion with or without cystectomy can be performed for end-stage cases.
  • ➤ Radiation cystitis is a common complication of pelvic radiotherapy with incidence rates ranging from 23% to 80%.

  • ➤ incidence rates ranging from 23% to 80%.

  • ➤ Haematuria is a common symptom.
  • ➤ The end stage is a small, fibrotic bladder
  • ➤ Rx- Cystoscopic management with fulguration or laser to bleeding vessels OR urinary diversion with or without cystectomy can be performed for end-stage cases.
  • ➤ Ref : Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28 th edition pg 1514

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with hard painless testicular swelling. On investigations Alpha fetoprotein is 3080. No abdominal lump is felt. USG shows testicular mass with uniform echotexture and small areas of necrosis. Surrounding structures are normal. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) High inguinal orchidectomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC). FNAC is not typically used for the initial evaluation of testicular masses because it can potentially seed the tumor along the needle track.
  • • Option A: Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC).
  • • not typically used for the initial evaluation of testicular masses
  • • Option B: Trucut biopsy. As with FNAC , a biopsy is not usually performed due to the risk of tumor seeding and because it may alter lymphatic drainage pathways.
  • • Option B: Trucut biopsy.
  • • FNAC
  • • biopsy is not usually performed due to the risk of tumor seeding
  • • may alter lymphatic drainage pathways.
  • • Option D: Positron emission tomography-computed tomography (PET-CT). While PET-CT may have a role in staging certain testicular tumors , it is not the initial step in the management of a suspected testicular cancer.
  • • Option D: Positron emission tomography-computed tomography (PET-CT).
  • • role in staging certain testicular tumors
  • • not the initial step in the management

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ High inguinal orchiectomy is the initial treatment step for suspected testicular tumors , providing both therapeutic and diagnostic benefits . Further management is guided by histological diagnosis and staging investigations post-orchiectomy.
  • ➤ High inguinal orchiectomy
  • ➤ initial treatment step for suspected testicular tumors
  • ➤ both therapeutic and diagnostic benefits
  • ➤ Testicular Tumours
  • ➤ Testicular Tumours
  • ➤ Testicular cancer is among the most common malignancies in young males Risk factors- cryptorchidism, family history of testicular cancer, and intratubular germ cell neoplasia. Most cases are germ cell tumours; others being stromal (Leydig cell) or sex cord (Sertoli cell) tumors. Germ cell tumours can be broadly divided into seminoma and nonseminoma germ cell tumours (NSGCTs). The majority of seminomas are classic (85%); the remainder are either anaplastic or spermatocytic seminoma. NSGCTs are further divided into embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac or endodermal sinus tumours, choriocarcinoma, teratoma, and mixed germ cell tumours. Any solid intratesticular mass is considered malignant unless proven otherwise. Initial treatment of suspected testicular tumour is high inguinal orchiectomy, which involves removal of the testicle and spermatic cord at the level of the inguinal ring. After radical orchiectomy, the patient should undergo disease staging, including cross-sectional, contrast-enhanced imaging of the abdomen and pelvis and chest imaging, either chest radiography in low-risk patients or cross-sectional chest imaging in patients with high-risk disease.

questions.text: A patient present with a history of dull, aching pain in the left scrotum and a physical examination that reveals a palpable 'bag of worms' consistent with varicocele. Varicoceles are more commonly found on the left side due to the anatomical drainage pattern of the left testicular vein into which of the following vessels?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Renal vein

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Renal vein is the correct answer . The left testicular vein drains into the left renal vein . The angle at which the left testicular vein enters the left renal vein , along with the potential compression between the superior mesenteric artery and aorta (the 'nutcracker' effect), can lead to increased pressure in the vein and the development of a varicocele.
  • • Renal vein
  • • correct answer
  • • left testicular vein drains into the left renal vein
  • • angle at which the left testicular vein enters the left renal vein
  • • potential compression between the superior mesenteric artery and aorta
  • • lead to increased pressure
  • • vein and the development of a varicocele.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The left testicular vein drains into the left renal vein , which is associated with a higher incidence of varicocele on the left side due to increased venous pressure and anatomical compression factors.
  • ➤ left testicular vein drains into the left renal vein
  • ➤ higher incidence of varicocele on the left side due to increased venous pressure
  • ➤ anatomical compression factors.
  • ➤ Varicocele
  • ➤ Varicocele
  • ➤ It is the dilatation and increased tortuosity of testicular veins (pampiniform plexus), mostly results from defective valves in testicular veins , but renal vein can also be involved . Mostly present in adolescence or early adulthood. Occurs predominantly on the left side. This is because the right testicular vein joins the low pressure IVC (below the right renal vein), whereas the left testicular vein joins the left renal vein, in which venous pressure is higher. Left varicoceles are more common than right because: The ‘nutcracker’ effect that occurs when the left testicular vein gets trapped between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta. This causes venous compression and testicular vein obstruction. Angulation (90 degrees) at the junction of the left testicular vein and the left renal vein also causes a high pressure in left testicular vein.

questions.text: Which of these testicular tumors is highly malignant and metastasis commonly via hematogenous and lymphatic route?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Choriocarcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Seminoma. While seminomas are a type of germ cell tumor , they typically metastasize via the lymphatic route , and hematogenous spread is less common.
  • • Option A: Seminoma.
  • • type of germ cell tumor
  • • metastasize via the lymphatic route
  • • Option B: Teratoma. Teratomas are germ cell tumors that consist of various tissue types , do not have the same rapid and widespread metastatic pattern as choriocarcinomas.
  • • Option B: Teratoma.
  • • germ cell tumors
  • • consist of various tissue types
  • • not have the same rapid
  • • widespread metastatic pattern as choriocarcinomas.
  • • Option D: Leydig cell tumor. Most Leydig cell tumors are benign and those that are malignant usually do not spread as aggressively as choriocarcinomas.
  • • Option D: Leydig cell tumor.
  • • Leydig cell tumors
  • • benign
  • • those that are malignant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Choriocarcinoma is a highly malignant testicular tumor that metastasizes early via both lymphatic and hematogenous routes and is associated with elevated levels of HCG.
  • ➤ Choriocarcinoma
  • ➤ highly malignant testicular tumor
  • ➤ metastasizes early via both lymphatic and hematogenous routes
  • ➤ elevated levels of HCG.
  • ➤ Seminomas metastasise mainly via the lymphatics and haematogenous spread is uncommon . The lymphatic drainage of the testes is to the para-aortic lymph nodes near the origin of the gonadal vessels. The contralateral para-aortic lymph nodes are sometimes involved by tumour spread, but the inguinal lymph nodes are affected only if the scrotal skin is involved. Teratomas consist of different tissues derived from ectoderm, endoderm and mesoderm. Immature components are often neuroectodermal or mesenchymal tissue, while more mature tissue is often cystic with epithelial differentiation or consists of smooth muscle, connective tissue or cartilage. All can metastasise. Choriocarcinoma. This is part of a testicular GCT in 25% of tumours in adults. It very seldom appears as the single tumour component. Choriocarcinoma is almost never seen in childhood. This tumour produces human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG), which can be detected in blood. This is a highly malignant tumor that metastasizes early via both the lymphatics and the bloodstream. Leydig cell : Most of these tumours are benign. Malignant transformation occurs in 10% and is related to increased size (>5 cm).

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with urinary hesitancy, decreased stream, and a sensation of incomplete bladder emptying. He has been taking anticoagulation for previous stroke. He has been diagnosed with benign prostatic hyperplasia, and his prostate gland is estimated to be significantly enlarged on digital rectal examination. USG prostate shows a gland of size 80-85g. Considering his diagnosis and the size of the prostate, which treatment modality is preferred for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) HOLEP

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: TURP. While TURP is the gold standard treatment for BPH , it may not be the most suitable option for very large prostate glands due to the risk of increased operative time and complications.
  • • Option A: TURP.
  • • TURP is the gold standard treatment for BPH
  • • Option C: Intra-urethral stent. This is generally used as a temporary measure or for patients who are not candidates for surgery.
  • • Option C: Intra-urethral stent.
  • • used as a temporary measure
  • • Option D: Cryoablation. This treatment modality is not the first line for benign prostatic hyperplasia and is more commonly used for prostate cancer.
  • • Option D: Cryoablation.
  • • not the first line for benign prostatic hyperplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HOLEP is the preferred treatment modality for patients with very large prostate glands due to its efficacy in removing a significant amount of prostate tissue with a low risk of complications.
  • ➤ HOLEP
  • ➤ preferred treatment modality for patients with very large prostate glands
  • ➤ efficacy in removing a significant amount of prostate tissue
  • ➤ low risk of complications.
  • ➤ Interventional measures include transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), which remains the gold standard; Consider HOLEP (holmium laser enucleation of the prostate), open/ robotic simple prostatectomy for large glands. New minimally invasive treatment options that are available to patients include prostate artery embolisation (PAE), water vapour prostate treatment, prostatic urethral lift (Urolift) and water jet treatment (Aquablation).

questions.text: A 54-year-old male 3 months ago started to feel a bulging lesion on the surface of glans penis. known smoker for 20 years, no multiple sexual partners and no viral infection. Patient was circumcised. He started having difficulty in micturition. He went to the surgery OP. the glans penis was fully covered and invasion was detected in the urethral meatus. Biopsy was taken from the patient and the urethral meatus was opened. The biopsy result was squamous cell carcinoma. In the above condition which group of lymph nodes enlarge?

options.label: A
options.text: Medial Members of the Upper Horizontal Group of Superficial Inguinal Lymph Nodes

options.label: B
options.text: Lateral Members of the Upper Horizontal Group of Superficial Inguinal Lymph Nodes

options.label: C
options.text: Lower / Vertical Group of Superficial Inguinal Lymph Nodes

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Deep Inguinal Lymph Nodes

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. These lymph nodes are part of the superficial inguinal group and are located just below the inguinal ligament . They receive lymphatic drainage from the penile and scrotal area . While these nodes can be involved in penile cancers , they are not typically the first group of nodes to show enlargement.
